Liter first being used in temples as blinds or curtains
since their introduction from China during the regime of
the Lshi-kaga Shogunate, the cloth curtain came to replace

and sun...but letting the customer walk in.
The NOKEN came, in due time, to be looked on as a shop symbol.
L kind of trade mark and status of reputation wound up in
one.
Foreover, an interesting custom In own as nore-wake or NOREN
dividing still prevails in Japan. L shop apprentice, having
become an expert in a certain trade and having served out
his contracted term of service is formally authorized to
begin business. He may do it with the use of his master’s
seal, coat-of-arms of noren. This, by the way, is a special
and great honor, accorded only the best and most worthy
apprentices.
Well, the noren has come to stand not only for the shop
and its wares but also for its credit or good-will. So that
any prospective buyer or a shop (apart from paying for the
building, equipment, stock, etc.) is required to pay for
’’noren” as a form of good-will payment.
Used only before ordinary Japanese “sake” or rice-wine shops
and restaurants there is a type of noren generally known
as nawa-noren meaning rope curtain. But here is the original
purposes From the Chinese characters which compose the word,
“noren” implies “rattan blind,” This was transformed over
the years to mean cloth curtains. Of course, these curtains
or blinds served to keep out rain, wind, and bad weather.
They still do today.
